While the counselor is giving out referrals they talk about basic licensing regulations and what to look for in a quality program.  They also walk the parents through the different steps of the screening process and discuss different plans providers may have developed in the case of emergency.

VOLUNTEERS:  Adults,18 and older are needed during the daytime for administrative duties.
eligibility: Anyone looking for child care.
application_process: Either walk-in or call for information.
name: Child Care Links Resource and Referral Center, Cecil and Harford

description:
OVERVIEW: Provides parents/guardians with lists of certified day care providers or centers in their neighborhoods or near their workplaces.  

SERVICES:

1) RESOURCE AND REFERRAL COUNSELING: Maintains a computerized listing of all registered family child care providers, licensed center-based and school-age programs, certified camp programs, accredited nursery schools, kindergartens and Head Start programs in Maryland. Has listings of programs that specialize in providing care for children with special needs or provide overnight care and emergency shelter for children.  Counselors discuss each caller's child care needs, preferences and ability to pay and then provide a list of suitable child care providers. 

2) SOFTWARE PROGRAMS: Offers the LOCATE COMMUNITY RESOURCES software program and database for lease. Designed to quickly and easily help users access referrals to a wide array of local, state, and national family support services. Call for information on pricing and hardware requirements.

name: LOCATE: Child Care, Maryland

description:
OVERVIEW: Provides information, referral and training to parents, child care providers, advocates and employers to expand and enhance the early childhood education and child care available to Maryland children.

MEMBERSHIP: Center membership fee per year: 1-24 staff, $50; 25+ staff, $100; For home-based child care providers, $25; individuals, $35. Members receive copies of the annual report and public policy reports for free; reduced admission to training programs and special events, such as parent educational programs; and free admission to the library.

SERVICES:
1) INFORMATION AND REFERRAL: Provides information on all regulated child care programs in the state, including child care homes, child care centers, and summer camps. (See separate listing LOCATE: Child Care, Maryland)

2) FREE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE: Provides basic information on starting and maintaining child care programs, including family child care homes. 

3) TRAINING PROGRAMS: Provided for all licensed child care programs. Attendance required by law. Fees range from $15-$35. 

4) WORK/FAMILY RESOURCES: Provided to interested employers considering implementing work/family options, including benefits leave policies and programs.

5) LIBRARY: Provides a reference-only library at 608 Water Street. Admission is $2.50 for non-members, free for members. Information on child development, children's policies, work and family issues, child care, establishing & maintaining a child care business and reports on national studies concerning children's issues. Limited material available on tape. Fee for copies of materials: $.10 per page.

6) COMMUNITY OUTREACH: Works with advocates and community planners by sharing information, statistics, and policy issues.

7) MARYLAND EIC CAMPAIGN: Coordinates a statewide public awareness campaign about the Earned Income Tax Credit. Partners in the campaign include nonprofit organizations, state and local government agencies, and businesses.  The EIC is a federal tax benefit for low-income and moderate-income individuals who work full-time, part-time, or part of the year. The EIC is designed primarily to benefit families. Workers who qualify for the EIC and file a federal tax return can get back some or all of the federal income tax that was taken out of their pay during the year. They may also get additional cash back as an income supplement. 

VOLUNTEERS: None needed at this time.

The Alliance was created to conduct research, do policy analysis, develop national programs and increase public awareness of family care giving issues.

description:
OVERVIEW: Provides support services to children and adults with cerebral palsy and other disabilities so they may live productive and independent lives.

SERVICES:

1) COMMUNITY SUPPORTED LIVING ARRANGEMENTS: Offers services and support which enable individuals to remain in their homes. Includes personal attendant and companion care, community integration training, and case management services.

2) ADULT DAY PROGRAMS: Offers five medical day centers which provide on-site nursing and health monitoring. Daily activities include arts & crafts, exercise, current events, sensory stimulation, physical management, music and more. 

3) DEVELOPMENTAL LEARNING CENTERS: Provides educational programs and therapies for children and young adults ages 2-21 years with physical and intellectual challenges. Operates an Intensive V Preschool Program that prepares children intellectually, physically and emotionally for entrance into the public school system.

4) ADVOCACY: Provides groups organized and run by program participants to ensure appropriate freedoms and protection. Individuals, families, and friends are encouraged to be active in all areas of service planning and delivery, including development of support plans.

5) FAMILY SUPPORT SERVICES: Provides support to families of children in need of 
one-time, minimal or ongoing supports, such as linkage and referral, outreach, crisis intervention, follow-up and monitoring. 

6) EMPLOYMENT SERVICES: Provide assistance to adults ages 21 years and older with job selection, interviewing, training, and maintaining both paid and volunteer positions within the community.
                                             
VOLUNTEERS: Needed for fundraising/development, adult recreation, support services, residential services, day program, transportation, office, employment services, and child and youth services. Contact local office for more information.

Home visits: Other, see notes
eligibility: Persons with disabilities, including mental retardation, cerebral palsy, epilepsy and spina bifida.
name: United Cerebral Palsy Maryland, Inc., Hagerstown

description:
OVERVIEW: Provides support services to children and adults with cerebral palsy and other disabilities so they may live productive and independent lives.

SERVICES:

1) DELREY PRESCHOOL PROGRAM: Provided for children ages 2-6 years with cerebral palsy and other disabilities. Goal is to prepare them intellectually, physically and emotionally for entrance into the public school system.

2) DELREY CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS: Provided for children and youth from 
pre-school to 21 years of age. Offers educational and therapeutic programs for Baltimore City and County residents. See list of locations - Arbutus and Harford Development Centers.

3) ADULT DAY PROGRAMS: Offered to persons with developmental disabilities ages 21 years and older. Day Habitation Program focuses on development of interpersonal, vocational and employment skills. Medical Adult Day Care is provided to adults with significant or chronic health issues.

4) EMPLOYMENT SERVICES: Provide assistance to adults ages 21 years and older with job selection, interviewing, training, and maintaining both paid and volunteer positions within the community.

5) RESIDENTIAL PROGRAMS: Provides barrier-free housing, personal care assistance, and life skills training for adults with disabilities in agency-owned or leased single-family homes and apartments throughout the State. 

6) IN-HOME SUPPORT PROGRAM: Offers services to adults with developmental disabilities such as personal care, housekeeping, financial counseling and case management so that they may remain in their own homes. Provides the following:

o COMMUNITY SUPPORTED LIVING ARRANGEMENTS (CSLA): Provides support to individuals in need of long term, ongoing support.
 
o INDIVIDUAL SUPPORT SERVICES (ISS): Provides supports to individuals in need of one time or minimal ongoing supports, such as funding to purchase assistive technology or make accessible modifications to one's home; funding to provide personal care to an individual for a few hours each week, etc. 

o FAMILY SUPPORT SERVICES (FSS):  Provides supports to families of children 21 years or younger to enable them to care for the child in their homes.

7) TRANSPORTATION: Provides lift-equipped buses and vans to transport program participants to day programs, places of employment, medical appointments, recreational outings, and local community sites. Call for information.

8) RECREATIONAL PROGRAMS: Provides a variety of social activities for adults.

9) RESPITE CARE: Provided to families and caregivers for short-term care of individuals, 
in or out of the home, allowing the family a time of rest. Fees based on a sliding scale. 

10) ASSISTIVE TECHNOLOGY: Offers assessments, extended training, and a lending library of various assistive technology devices to persons with disabilities.
 
11) ADVOCACY: Works with lawmakers, administration officials, and community leaders to improve the lives of individuals with disabilities and their families.

12) DONATIONS: Accepts cash, checks, credit cards, gifts of marketable securities, planned gifts such as bequests and gift annuities, and used vehicles.

VOLUNTEERS: Occasionally accepts volunteers ages 16 years and older to assist with adult day care, work as school aides, perform clerical work in the office and assist with fundraising events.

OTHER LOCATIONS:

1) Headquarters, 1700 Reisterstown Road, Suite 226, Baltimore, MD 21208-1417.  410-484-4540 or 800-451-2452; fax 410-486-3825.

2) Sulphur Spring Center, 1660 Sulphur Spring Road, Baltimore, MD 21227-2539.  410-242-9010 or 800-447-7142; fax 410-242-9707.

3)  Essextowne Center, 435-437 Maryland Avenue, Baltimore, MD 21221-6706. 410-574-7696 or 800-762-6251; fax 410-574-6590.

4) Delrey School, 18 Delrey Ave., Catonsville, MD 21228-3420. 410-744-3151; fax 410-744-8467.

description:
OVERVIEW: Fights for the rights of children and adults with cerebral palsy and other disabilities to live a full life in the community. These rights included education, employment, and housing. 

SERVICES:

1) ADULT DAY PROGRAMS: Offered to persons with developmental disabilities ages 21 years and older. Day Habitation Program focuses on development of interpersonal, vocational and employment skills. Medical Adult Day Care is provided to adults with significant or chronic health issues. Programs are open Monday through Friday, 7:30am to 4:30pm.

2) EMPLOYMENT SERVICES: Provide assistance to adults ages 21 years and older with job selection, interviewing, training, and maintaining both paid and volunteer positions within the community.

3) RESIDENTIAL PROGRAMS: Provides barrier-free housing, personal care assistance, and life skills training for adults with disabilities in agency-owned or leased single-family homes and apartments throughout the State. 

4) IN-HOME SUPPORT PROGRAM: Offers services to adults with developmental disabilities such as personal care, housekeeping, financial counseling and case management so that they may remain in their own homes. Provides the following:

       o Community Supported Living Arrangements (CSLA): Provides support to individuals in need of long term, ongoing support.
 
       o Individual Support Services (ISS): Provides supports to individuals in need of one time or minimal ongoing supports, such as funding to purchase assistive technology or make accessible modifications to one's home; funding to provide personal care to an individual for a few hours each week, etc. 

       o Family Support Services (FSS):  Provides supports to families of children 21 years or younger to enable them to care for the child in their homes.

5) TRANSPORTATION: Provides lift-equipped buses and vans to transport program participants to day programs, places of employment, medical appointments, recreational outings, and local community sites. Call for information.

6) RECREATIONAL PROGRAMS: Provides a variety of social activities for adults.

7) RESPITE CARE: Provided to families and caregivers for short-term care of individuals, 
in or out of the home, allowing the family a time of rest. Fees based on a sliding scale. 

8) ASSISTIVE TECHNOLOGY: Offers assessments, extended training, and a lending library of various assistive technology devices to persons with disabilities.
 
9) ADVOCACY: Works with lawmakers, administration officials, and community leaders to improve the lives of individuals with disabilities and their families.

10) DONATIONS: Accepts cash, checks, credit cards, gifts of marketable securities, planned gifts such as bequests and gift annuities, and used vehicles.

VOLUNTEERS: Volunteers 16 and older welcomed to assist with adult day care, work as school aides, perform clerical duties in the office and assist with fundraising events.

Home visits: No
eligibility: Adults 21 and older with cerebral palsy or other disabilities.
fees: None or may vary depending upon service.
application_process: Call or visit web site for further information.
name: United Cerebral Palsy of Maryland, Frederick

description:
SERVICES:  Offers counseling and supportive services to unplanned, expectant parents.

1) COUNSELING SERVICES:  Assists pregnant women dealing with unplanned pregnancies evaluate their parenting readiness, deal with the realities of an unplanned pregnancy, and make decisions about adoption or parenting.  Individual and family counseling sessions are available and can continue indefinitely.

2) ADOPTION SERVICES:  Acts as an intermediary between expectant parents, and birth parents with decisions and options on adopting.  Provides training, counseling, and support services to domestic and international adoptive parents.

o Parents may participate in the selection of the adoptive parents and have an opportunity to meet them.
o Birth parents may place their child in interim foster care after birth while they reconsider their adoption plan, for up to 1 month.

3) ADOPTION SEARCH PROGRAM:  Anyone 21 years or older who was placed by Catholic Charities may request a search for their birth parents. Birth parents whose children are at least 21 years old, and placed through Catholic Charities may request search services.   There are fees for these services.  Provides support services to help deal with the outcome of such reunions.

description:
Offers opportunities for young college graduates to serve for one year in one of Catholic Charities' human service programs. Programs help children, the poor, the homeless, the elderly, and the developmentally disabled. All placements are full-time positions. 

Participants receive the following benefits:
o Room and board
o Health Insurance
o Monthly food and living stipend
o Vacation
o Student loan deferment (when applicable)
o AmeriCorps Volunteer Stipend (if approved)

ELIGIBILITY: Applicants should meet the following guidelines:
o Make a one-year commitment to Project Serve
o Have the degree of certification necessary for work in their chosen program
o Be willing to live in a community of volunteers
o Be committed to working with people who are poor or elderly
o Be open to individuals of different religious, political, cultural and social backgrounds
o Be free from addiction to drugs or alcohol
o If necessary, submit to a background check

APPLICATION PROCESS: Complete application which consists of a candidate questionnaire, a biographical essay, and three references. Applications can be obtained through the Project Serve office or online. After completing the application candidates will review available placement opportunities, choose two programs for site visits, visit selected program sites or conduct telephone interviews with program supervisors, and discuss an appropriate placement with the Project Serve director.

DONOR SERVICES: Accepts vehicles, real estate, life insurance and in-kind contributions.

VOLUNTEERS: Volunteer opportunities are only available for eligible college students and recent college graduates. No additional volunteers recruited at this time.

Home visits: No
eligibility: See notes.

OVERVIEW: Connects people in need to resources, daily meals, and supported efforts towards employment and housing.  Houses Christopher Place Employment Academy and the Maryland Re-entry Partnership, see separate listings for both.

SERVICES:
1) Our Daily Bread Employment Services, see separate listing.

2) Our Daily Bread Meal Services, see separate listing.

3) Residential services for Christopher Place participants and graduates. See separate listing for Christopher Place Employment Academy. 

4) Recovery services:
    o Houses NA and AA meetings
    o Referrals to treatment facilities

5) Housing services:
    o Offers home ownership workshop
    o Referrals to emergency shelters and transitional housing opportunities

6) Health services:
    o Basic health exams by appointment
    o Referrals to health care and mental health services

7) Legal services:
    o Basic legal services by appointment
    o Referrals to legal service providers

8) Mail services: Allows use of mailing address for those without a permanent home. 

9) Information and Referral services: To community social service providers and benefits assistance.

10) EARNBENEFITS: Offers free assistance to anyone with financial difficulties.  Screens clients to see what benefits they are eligible for (food stamps, prescription assistance, health care etc.) and completes applications electronically.  Has a trained case manager on staff who is knowledgeable about benefits and navigating the system to receive them.

11)  **TAX ASSISTANCE 2008: Offered Mon - Fri, 11:30AM-3:30PM; Sat, 10AM-1PM, Jan 19-April 15, 2008, by appointment only. Call 410-234-8008.  
Must bring the following: 
  --  Valid photo ID for self and spouse
  --  A Social Security card for EACH family member.
  --  W-2 forms for all jobs worked in 2007.
  --  Child care provider - name, address and tax ID number.
  --  All banking account information (a voided check and/or savings deposit slip). 
  --  A copy of last year's tax return.
  --  Any document or information about money received from the IRS, including the advanced Child Tax Credit.
  --  All 1099 forms for other income, if any.
  --  Any other tax related documents.
NOTE: Every adult listed on the tax form must come to sign the return.

description:
1) RESIDENTIAL TREATMENT PROGRAM: Offers residential treatment for emotionally disabled children ages 5-14 for whom less restrictive interventions and services have proven inadequate. Provides a comprehensive plan for therapeutic services based on a thorough diagnostic assessment.  

2) INTENSIVE TREATMENT UNIT: Offers a 6-bed, short term, co-ed treatment program designed for behaviorally needy children requiring a higher level of treatment.  

3) THERAPEUTIC GROUP HOME: Provides six beds in a community-based, home-like environment  for boys ages 9-14 with serious emotional and behavioral issues. Goals of the program are to step-down from residential treatment and build skills.

4) VILLA MARIA SCHOOL: Offers comprehensive special education and therapeutic services to students ages 3-14. Maintains three campuses; two in Baltimore County and one in Baltimore City. Therapeutic Extended School Day is also offered Monday-Thursday until 6PM providing students with remediation/tutoring, behavioral treatment and therapeutic recreational programming.  

5) IN-HOME INTERVENTION:  Provides a wrap-around service for children who are awaiting placement or being discharged from an out-of-home placement. Services include an average of two home visits per week; a 24-hour, 7-day a week crisis intervention service, counseling, parent training; consultation with school staff; and support services.

6) THERAPEUTIC WEEKEND RESPITE PROGRAM: Offers a planned respite within a structured residential treatment center to help prevent out-of-home placement.

7) THERAPEUTIC AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAM: Offers therapeutic services, educational re-mediation and therapeutic recreation for children at risk of requiring a more restrictive placement.

8)  SCHOOL-BASED CRISIS STABILIZATION AND DIAGNOSTIC SERVICE:  Identifies and addresses the clinical needs of children with emotional disabilities and determines an appropriate educational plan.

9) B-CARS (Baltimore Child and Adolescent Response System): Offers a psychiatric crisis response system for Baltimore City children and adolescents. Reduces unnecessary hospitalizations and offers community based alternatives to decrease lengths of stay in hospitals. 

10) BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CLINICS: Provides behavioral health services including individual, group and family therapy, psychiatric evaluation, psychological testing and medication management.

11) BRIDGES TO SUCCESS: Provides intensive case management and home base services to families of youth with histories of truancy, runaway behavior and other significant behavior problems.

12) SAFE START: Provides screening and intervention for at risk Head Start families. Services include an initial screening for abuse and neglect risk factors, referral for adjunctive services for clinical treatment and outreach services to the home.

13)  HEAD START CONSULTATION: Provides behavioral consultation and training to Head Start programs in Baltimore City and Baltimore County.  

14)  HOME BASED RESPITE: Provides in-home respite for parents of emotionally disabled children. Includes skill building activities and recreation.

15)  SCHOOL BASED MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES: Provides mental health services in schools in Baltimore City and surrounding counties.

16) SCHOOL CONSULTATION PROGRAM: Offers student screening; skill building; group work with students; support services to faculty; family consultations; parent-teacher conferences; information and referral to appropriate community resources.

AGES SERVED: Varies with programs.

PROGRAM LOCATIONS: 

1)  Baltimore Child and Adolescent Response System-B-Cars (Baltimore City)
2)  Villa Maria Behavioral Health Clinic (Frederick)
3)  Villa Maria Behavioral Health Clinic (Fall Staff)
4)  Villa Maria Behavioral Health Clinic (Abingdon)
5)  Villa Maria of Anne Arundel (Gambrills)
6)  Villa Maria of Mountain Maryland (Cumberland)
7)  Villa Maria of Washington County (Hagerstown)
8)  Villa Maria After School Program (Lansdowne)                  

VOLUNTEERS: Volunteers, ages 17 and older, are welcome. Opportunities are available for recreation programs, library services and clerical work.

description:
OVERVIEW: Offers mental health services to survivors of torture and war trauma from all over the world.

SERVICES:   
1) Provides psychological assessments, individual and family psychotherapy, and group treatment depending on the clients needs.  Sessions may last several weeks or months.  

2) Can provide a psychological report for a client's asylum interview and/or prepare a full psychological evaluation for use as expert asylum court testimony.  

3) Provides social services support, information and referrals that help address a range of concerns that affect the survivors.  These may include psychosocial adjustment, living situation, medical and nutritional status or cultural and linguistic barriers. 

DONATIONS: In need of clothing donations (please call first to see what type is needed) and laptops no older than Windows 2000. 
VOLUNTEERS: Adults, 18 and over to help as an interpreter, client befriender or with administrative duties.  Contact Andrea Rackowski, 410-464-9006.

description:
OVERVIEW:  Provides service and community civic engagement to students from culturally and economically diverse backgrounds.

SERVICES:  

1)  SERVICE & ACTION:  A service learning approach is designed to give high school students hands-on experience.  This enables students to gain confidence and competence, while developing a closer connection to the communities where they live.

2)  OPERATION A.W.A.R.E:  Designed to heighten the awareness of middle schools students to the problems in their communities and empower them to utilize their unique talents in the field of community organizing.

3)  ADVOCACY TRAINING:  Training includes trips to Annapolis to experience advocacy first-hand and meet with legislators, instructions on how to write letters to governmental officials which is accessible in hard copy.

4)  STUDENT EXECUTIVE COUNCIL:  Participating schools have 2 student representatives who are responsible for motivating other students and organizing Students Sharing Clubs.  Each representative attends a week long Summer Leadership Training, trained to facilitate teams of high school students.

5) MIDDLE SCHOOL SERVICE LEARNING CAMP: A two week camp in July that educates students about the fundamentals of citizenship. Assists in creating and implementing service learning projects.

VOLUNTEERS:  College students welcome for service team leaders.

Home visits: No

description:
OVERVIEW: Assists in protecting the public from attorneys who fail to maintain high standards. Function is solely disciplinary in nature and does not include the recovery of fees and other damages.  To file a complaint, either complete a complaint form or write a letter to the Commission.  Include in the letter your name, address and phone number; the name, address and phone number of the attorney in question and a description of the complaint.

The Commission begins an investigation when a complaint is received. When appropriate, further action may be taken by the Court of Appeals.  If investigation is required the complainant is referred to a peer review panel who will discuss the matter with the complainant and the attorney to determine if conciliation is possible.  If further action is required the complaint is sent to the commission.  Both the complainant and respondent are kept up to date on the progress of the complaint through the system

VOLUNTEERS:  Volunteers are needed to serve as public members of the peer review in various counties throughout MD.  For more information contact Truc Lam 240-386-3711.

Home visits: No
eligibility: Anyone with a complaint against a Maryland licensed attorney.

description:
OVERVIEW: St. Vincent de Paul of Baltimore helps low-income and homeless persons meet basic needs and achieve self-sufficiency by providing food, clothing, housing, education, employment, burial assistance and other services.

SERVICES:
1) SAMARITAN CENTER: Helps low-income and homeless persons residing in Baltimore City resolve emergency needs through direct financial assistance in utility & transportation assistance and eviction prevention.

2) CAMP ST. VINCENT: Provides a free summer day camp for children ages 5-11 years from households experiencing homelessness and poverty in Baltimore City & County. The Camp's structured outdoor recreation program includes swimming, arts & crafts, singing, reading & math, games, sports, nature exploration and character development. Breakfast, lunch and transportation are provided. Baltimore City and Baltimore County children who are eligible for the free school lunch program are eligible for the camp.

3) BEANS & BREAD OUTREACH CENTER: A resource center shelter for hungry, homeless and those in need. Provides meals, counseling, case management, information and referral, basic health care and other services.

4) ST. AMBROSE OUTREACH CENTER: Provides comprehensive adult education and employment services, after-school and summer camp services, meals, and emergency & supplemental food to help persons living in poverty become self-sufficient, realize their potential and improve their quality of life.

5) FREDERICK OZANAM HOUSE: Provides recovery-based transitional housing, case management, employment readiness and placement, life skills training, and other support to 20 homeless men. Located next to Beans & Bread.

6) PRISON OUTREACH: Supports the work of chaplains and volunteers who minister to incarcerated men and women and to their families in Baltimore City and Central & Western Maryland.

7) SARAH'S HOPE OUTREACH CENTER: Provides 24-hour shelter and support services to help homeless women and children achieve self-sufficiency and attain permanent housing. Clients also receive outside services, such as employment, mental health and substance abuse counseling; adult education; and housing assistance. 

8) MOBILE CLOTHING BANK: Program that distributes clothing, shoes, and personal care items to persons who are homeless at various shelters in Baltimore City and Baltimore & Anne Arundel Counties. also conducts street distributions in Baltimore City.

9) COTTAGE AVENUE COMMUNITY: Transitional housing program designed to help 15 homeless families make the transition from emergency shelters to permanent housing and self-sufficiency. Located in a neighborhood setting, the program offers counseling, case management, employment, life skills training and other support.

10) HEAD START: A comprehensive federal program for pre-school children that offers developmentally appropriate educational, health and social services to children and their families to prepare children for kindergarten.

o Northwest: 5001 West Park Heights Avenue, Baltimore, MD 21215. 410-542-4242.
o Southeast: 242 South Patterson Park Avenue, Baltimore, MD 21231. 410-276-5724. 

11) ADELANTE FAMILIA: A bilingual program, provides culturally competent and linguistically sensitive domestic violence prevention and crisis intervention services to Spanish-speaking immigrant families.

12) HOME CONNECTIONS: Provides 28 chronically homeless persons with immediate access to permanent housing, as well as intensive case management and other support services.

13) LEARN TO EARN AT ST. AMBROSE: A workforce development program helping unemployed and underemployed persons find and retain jobs through skills assessment, adult education, job skills and readiness training, like skills classes, mentoring, peer support, career planning, and employment retention services.

13) YOUTH PLACE AT ST. AMBROSE: Offers after-school and evening academic & social development services to children and youth ages 6-18 years, such as tutoring, computer instruction, SAT prep, a book club, etc.

14) FOODSHARE: Distributes federal surplus food to over 140 food pantries and 40 soup kitchens in Baltimore City, as part of the Maryland Emergency Food Assistance Program. 

15) BURIAL ASSISTANCE:   Provides burial plots to indigent deceased persons at Sacred Heart of Jesus Cemetery in Southeast Baltimore.  For more information call 410-547-5377. 

VOLUNTEERS: Adult volunteers are welcome. Contact individual programs for age requirements and duties.

Home visits: No
eligibility: Open to anyone in need of emergency assistance.  Also see notes.

Has the authority to subpoena information and witnesses, to hold public hearings when reconciliation attempts fail, to issue cease and desist orders, and to take unresolved cases into court through the City Law Department.

description:
OVERVIEW:
Sells vehicles to low income individuals/families. Provides a six-month warranty. Buyer is responsible for insurance, taxes, tags and title fees.

ELIGIBILITY: 
Recipients must be
     o low income and unable to otherwise purchase a car
     o have a job or verifiable job offer
     o have no other vehicle in the household 
     o able to pay for insurance, taxes, tags and title
     o no extensive criminal background
     o drug free      
     o insurable, no DUIs, relatively clean driving record
     o be willing to take a 12-month loan to pay for car 

Car fees range from $900 to $1150 per car and the monthly payment is $85 to $99 per month. Each recipient is guaranteed a loan without regard to credit history. 

DONATIONS: Accepts donations of cars built since 1995 or in good running condition. Will pick up.

VOLUNTEERS: Volunteers 18 and older are welcome for general office and automobile (mechanical) duties.

Home visits: No
eligibility: Low income. See notes.
name: Vehicles For Change

description:
OVERVIEW:  Offers an intensive home and community-based family preservation clinical program designed to address the multiple needs of juvenile offenders. Targets factors in each youth's social network that are contributing to his/her antisocial behavior. Focuses on changing the known causes and risk factors for offending, including characteristics of the individual youth, family, peer relations, school functioning, and the neighborhood.

SERVICES:
1) PARENTING SKILLS:  Demonstrates the skills and resources needed to address difficulties and to improve discipline practices.

2) YOUTH EMPOWERMENT: Demonstrates and teaches ways of coping with the pressures and problems associated with family, peers, school and neighborhood and to decrease association with deviant peers while increasing association with pro-social peers.

3) INTENSIVE THERAPY: Intervention strategies include the use of strategic family therapy, structural family therapy, and cognitive behavior therapies.

4) THERAPIST AVAILABILITY: Therapist intervention available 24 hours/day, 7 days per week on-call.

VOLUNTEERS:  No volunteers opportunities are available at this time.

Home visits: Yes
eligibility: Chronic, violent, or substance abusing juvenile offenders and their families.
application_process: Referral form required, and can be obtained through Bureau of Mental Health, schools, probation officers, DSS or other mental health service providers.

description:
OVERVIEW: Provides clinics for testing and treating tuberculosis, flu  and rabies vaccinations; public health facility surveillance; a colorectal cancer program; STD services; validation of travel certificates, a women's cancer protection program, and dental services.

SERVICES:
1) CHEST CLINIC: For the purpose of diagnosing tuberculosis. When medically indicated, services include tuberculin testing, bacteriological investigation, x-ray exams and TB medications. Call 410-887-2711. No charge.

2) DENTISTRY: Provides general dental care for persons ages 3-18 years, 60 years and older, and pregnant women of any age. Services are provided at Eastern Family Resource Center, 410-887-6440 and Liberty Family Resource Center, 410-887-0613. The Dental Access Program is a reduced fee dental service in private dental offices for those who are income eligible and lack dental insurance. 

3) INFLUENZA IMMUNIZATION CLINICS: Provides low-cost flu immunizations each fall.  Call 410-887-2723. Fees vary, call for quote.

4) MEDICAL ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH: Provides public health environment surveillance of acute, general and special hospitals, nursing homes, day care providers and other health care providers. Call 410-887-6006.

5) RABIES CLINIC: Provides rabies shots for dogs and cats, three months of age and older. Offered at multiple locations in the spring of each year.  Call 410-887-2724 or 410-887-2723. Call for fees.

6) STD SERVICES: Provides testing and treatment for all STDs, including HIV/AIDS. Available at the Woodlawn and Essex Health Centers. Call 410-887-3145.

7) VALIDATION OF TRAVEL CERTIFICATES: Information and validation for international travel. Call 410-887-2724.

8) WOMEN'S CANCER PROTECTION PROGRAM: Provides mammograms and GYN examinations for eligible clients ages 40 years and older with no insurance, or low income. Fees based on income (sliding scale). Call 410-887-3432 for information.

10) COLORECTAL CANCER PROGRAM: Offers screenings and information regarding prevention measures for persons ages 50 years and older who do not have health insurance. Call 410-887-3456. Persons ages 40-49 years, with family history of colorectal cancer may also be eligible if within income limits. Call 1- 866-MD-colon. Fees are on a sliding scale.

Home visits: No
eligibility: Most services open to the public. See notes for specific services.
fees: Varies for each program.  See notes.
application_process: Call appropriate number for more information.
name: Baltimore County Health Dept., Bureau of Disease Control

alternate_name: Baltimore County Bureau of Substance Abuse
description:
ELIGIBILITY: Residents ineligible for Medical Assistance, ineligible for treatment through the Veterans Association, no health insurance or the policy does not cover mental health or chemical dependency, and individual or family does not have means to pay for treatment.

SERVICES: 
1)  INFORMATION & REFERRAL: Provides referrals to adolescents and adults to appropriate substance abuse treatment, prevention and criminal justice programs that are part of the Baltimore County system.

2)  TREATMENT ACCESS PROGRAM: Consists of treatment slots paid for by a grant to serve medically indigent clients. Services include inpatient and outpatient detoxification, intensive outpatient and residential programs.

3) RAPID SCREEN SERVICES: Provides a rapid assessment combined with a rapid result urine screen for families in crisis, due to suspicions of drug use by their teen. Also offers court screenings for youth with substance-related charges or a known history of substance abuse.

4) COMMUNITY OUTREACH: Provides speakers, literature and an audiovisual resource library.

5) PREVENTION SERVICES: Coordinates a variety of prevention services including:  SADD (Students Against Drunk Drivers) chapters, after prom activities, underage drinking coalition.

VOLUNTEER: No volunteers are needed.

Home visits: No
eligibility: See notes.
application_process: Call for information. No referral necessary.

alternate_name: Bureau of Child, Adolescent & Reproductive Health
description:
1) BEHAVIOR CONSULTATION CLINICS:  Diagnosis, evaluation and management of public school children who exhibit characteristics of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Resource material is available as well. Call 410-887-2718 for information.

2) CHILDREN'S MEDICAL SERVICES:  Provides assistance in obtaining specialty medical care for children with chronic illness or disabling condition.  Medical and financial requirements.  Call 410-887-2718.

3) DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES:  Counseling and case management services are offered to persons with developmental disabilities from birth to age 21. Call 410-887-2720 for information.

4) SPEECH, LANGUAGE & HEARING SERVICES:  Comprehensive evaluations are offered and include hearing and speech assessments, hearing aid issues, and  treatment of speech and language problems for children of all ages. Call 410-887-6443.

5) FAMILY PLANNING:  Counseling and instruction concerning the full range of family planning methods are offered at all health centers (except Towson).  Call the nearest Health Center for intake. 410-887-3725.

6) HEALTHY KIDS PROGRAM:  Health care coordination and case management are offered to children from birth through age 20, who are receiving Medical Assistance. 410-887-2705.

7) HEALTHY START:  Offers home visiting services to Medicaid eligible postpartum women and at risk pregnant women.  Call 410-887-2705.

8) HIGH RISK INFANT/CHILDREN PROGRAM:  Children who are considered high risk because of low birth weight or known potential health problems are offered testing, counseling and specialized care.  Call 410-887-2705.

9) IMMUNIZATION OUTREACH:  Childhood immunizations are offered. Call 410-887-2705.

10) INFANTS AND TODDLERS PROGRAM:  (See separate listing.)

11) SCHOOL HEALTH:  Gives health consultation and HIV screening to Baltimore County public school elementary and special school children.  Call 410-887-2718.

12) WELL CHILD CLINICS:  Provides preventive care for children from birth through age 20 at the different health centers. Immunizations and physicals are included.  Call the nearest health center for information and intake. 410-887-2705, 2718.

13) WIC: Provides supplemental food vouchers and a nutrition program that helps pregnant women, new mothers, nursing mothers and households with children under five years old. Call 410-887-6003 for an appointment.

 ELIGIBILITY:  Effective April 5, 2007

The Teen Family Planning Clinic is open the 2nd and 4th Thursday of the month from 2:30-5:15PM.  The Adult Family Planning Clinic is open the 2nd Tuesday of the month from 8:45AM-2:30PM. 

3) HEALTH SCREENINGS: Provides blood pressure screening, pregnancy testing & counseling. Call for appointment. 

4) HEALTHY START: Home visiting services are provided to Medicaid eligible postpartum women and at risk pregnant women. 

5) IMMUNIZATIONS: Provided to children on 3rd Wednesday of the month from 1:00-3:30PM. Call for appointment. 

6) WELL CHILD CLINIC: Provides preventative care for uninsured children and young adults from infancy through age 21. Services include immunizations and school physicals. Clinic is open the 3rd Wednesday of the month from 8:30AM-12:30PM. Call for appointment.

alternate_name: Baltimore County Dept. of Health, Eastern Family Resource Center
description:
SERVICES: 
1) DENTISTRY: Provides general dental care to children ages 3-18 years, persons 60 years and older, and pregnant women. Eligibility limited to persons without insurance or medical assistance. No emergency services. Call 410-887-6440, Monday-Friday, 8AM-4PM.

2) FAMILY CENTERED HOME VISITING: Provides blood pressure monitoring and medication monitoring to homebound and elderly persons referred by their physicians. Call 410-887-2705.

3) FAMILY PLANNING: Provides counseling and instruction concerning the full range of family planning/birth control methods; gynecological services and screening for STDs.  (Both teens and adults). A colposcopy clinic is available to family planning patients with no insurance. Call 410-887-3422.

4) HEALTH SCREENING: Provides blood pressure screenings, pregnancy testing and counseling. 410-887-2705.

5) HEALTHY START: Home visiting services to Medicaid eligible postpartum women and at-risk pregnant women. Call 410-887-2705.

6) HIGH RISK INFANT: Testing, counseling and specialized care provided to children who are considered high risk because of low birth weight or known or potential health problems. Call 410-887-6456.

7) IMMUNIZATIONS: Provides free immunizations to children and adults. Call for an appointment at 410-887-6452.

8) SPEECH AND LANGUAGE SERVICES: Comprehensive evaluation is offered and includes hearing assessments, hearing aid checks and/or hearing aid issuance. Also provides testing and treatment for speech and language problems. Call 410-887-6443. By appointment only.

9) TUBERCULOSIS: Screenings are provided. Call 410-887-2711.

10) WIC: Provides supplemental food vouchers and a nutrition program for pregnant women, new mothers, nursing mothers and households with children under five years old. Call 410-887-0425.

ELIGIBILITY:  Effective April 5, 2007

FAMILY SIZE		GROSS MONTHLY INCOME

1)   $18, 889	                  5)   $44, 641
2)   $25, 327		6)   $51, 079
3)   $31, 765		7)   $57, 517                                    
4)   $38, 203		8)   $63, 955

Add an additional $6,000 for each person.       	     	

11)  TURNAROUND SEXUAL ASSAULT AND DOMESTIC VIOLENCE:  Victim counseling for children and adults, call  410-391-2396.

12) EASTERN AREA TREATMENT PROGRAM:  Provides outpatient individual, family and group substance abuse counseling.  Also provides a certified DWI/DUI education program.  A psychiatrist is available to prescribe and monitor medications for dual diagnosis clients. Call 410-887-6465.


VOLUNTEERS:  No volunteers opportunities at this time.

Home visits: Other, see notes
eligibility: Low income persons.  See notes or call specific program for guidelines.
fees: Sliding fee scale or None.  Call for more information.

description:
1) BEHAVIOR CONSULTATION CLINIC:  Provides diagnosis, evaluation and management of children who exhibit characteristics of ADD and who have learning difficulties.  Clinic is open every Monday from 8:30-11AM.  Call 410-887-2718.

2) FAMILY CENTERED HOME VISITING:  Provides blood pressure monitoring and medication monitoring to homebound and elderly persons referred by their physician. Call 410-887-6463.

3) FAMILY PLANNING:  Provides counseling and instruction concerning the full range of family planning/birth control methods; gynecological services and screening and treatment for STDs.  Teen Family Planning Clinic is open the 2nd and 4th Wednesday of the month from 2:30-5PM.  Adult Family Planning Clinic is open the 1st and 3rd Wednesday of the month from 8:30AM-2PM.

4) FREE AND ANONYMOUS HIV TESTING AND COUNSELING:  Testing and results are available on the 1st and 3rd Thursday of the month from 2-4PM.  Call 410-887-2437.

5) HEALTHY START:  Home visiting services to Medicaid eligible/at-risk postpartum and pregnant women.  Call 410-887-2705.

6) HEALTH SCREENINGS:  Provides blood pressure screenings and pregnancy testing and counseling. 410-887-0246. The 3rd Thursday of the month, 9AM-3PM.
  
7) IMMUNIZATIONS:  Provided to children up to 19 years of age, on the 2nd Tuesday of the month from 1-3PM.  Call 410-887-0246.

8) STD CLINIC:  Provides testing and treatment for all STDs. Clinic is open every Thursday evening from 5-6:45PM. Only the first 20 persons will be seen.

9) WELL CHILD CLINIC:  Provides preventative care for uninsured children, from infancy through age 21.  Services include immunizations and school physicals.  Clinic is open on the 2nd Tuesdays of the month from 8:30AM-12PM.

description:
1) CHEST CLINIC: For diagnosing tuberculosis. When medically indicated, services include TB testing, bacteriological investigation, x-ray exams and TB medications. Call 410-887-0607.

2) DENTISTRY: Provides general dental care to persons ages 3-18 years, 60 years of age and older, and pregnant women of any age. Must not have insurance. Call 410-887-0613.

3) FAMILY CENTERED HOME VISITING: Provides assessments and case management services to homebound and elderly persons referred by their physicians or a family member. Call 410-887-0607.

4) FAMILY PLANNING: Provides counseling and instruction concerning the full range of family planning/birth control methods, gynecological services, screening and treatment for STD's, immunizations and genetic screenings for Sickle Cell Anemia and Tay-Sachs Disease. Teen Family Planning and Adult Family Planning Clinics are available. Call 410-887-0607 for scheduling information.

5) FREE AND ANONYMOUS HIV TESTING AND COUNSELING: Testing sites are located throughout the county. Call 410-887-2437 for times and locations.

6) HEALTHY START: Home visiting services to Medicaid-eligible postpartum women and at-risk pregnant women. Call 410-887-2705.

7) HEALTH SCREENINGS: Provides blood pressure screenings by physician referral and pregnancy testing and counseling. Call 410-887-0607.

8) HIGH RISK INFANT/CHILDREN PROGRAM: For children considered high risk because of low birth weight or known potential health problems. Testing, counseling, and specialized care are offered. Call 410-887-0609.

9) IMMUNIZATIONS: Provided to children. Times vary. Call 410-887-0607.

10) WELL CHILD CLINIC: Provides preventative care for uninsured children and young adults, from birth through 21 years of age. Services include immunizations and school physicals. Please call for clinic locations and times. Call 410-887-0607.

description:
1) HOME HEALTH and HOSPITAL SUPPORT SERVICES:  Provides discharge planning and follow-up care for patients hospitalized in the county's acute general hospitals and other facilities. Services include occupational, physical and speech therapy, skilled nursing, medical social work, and home health aide. Accepts insurance and sliding fee scale. Call 410-887-2725.  

2) ADULT EVALUATION REVIEW SERVICES (AERS):  Offers assessment and case management for senior citizens and disabled adults to prevent unnecessary institutionalization. Call 410-887-2754. Service is free.

3) MEDICAL ASSISTANCE PERSONAL CARE PROGRAM:  Provides bathing, chores, and personal hygiene to Medical Assistance recipients. Call 410-887-2710 or 410-887-3485. Fees paid through Medical Assistance. 

4) MEDICAL ASSISTANCE TRANSPORTATION:  Provides MA recipients transportation to/from medical appointments ONLY IF no other mode of transportation (including public transportation) is available. This is a "last resort" service. Call 410-887-2828.

5) PRE-ADMISSION SCREENING/ANNUAL RESIDENT REVIEW:  Evaluates persons seeking admission to a nursing home and those nursing home residents who are suspected of or diagnosed with mental illness and/or mental retardation. Call 410-887-2754.  Service is free.

VOLUNTEERS:  Office volunteers accepted.

eligibility: See individual services.

description:
Provides a wide variety of HIV/AIDS related activities to the community in order to reduce HIV infection in the County, and to meet the needs of those already infected or affected.

SERVICES:
1)  ANONYMOUS & CONFIDENTIAL FREE AND HIV TESTING AND COUNSELING:             Provided at 3 Health Center locations.  For general information, call 410-887-2437.
	a) Essex Health Center on the 1st Thursday of the month.  From 2-4PM.
	b) Liberty Family Resource Center on the 2nd and 4th Monday of the month.     
                  From 5-7PM.
	c) Towson Health Center on the 2nd Wednesday of the month by appointment.                   Call 410-887-5993. 

2) CASE MANAGEMENT: Coordinates medical, social and financial services for HIV      
    positive clients.

3) HOUSING: Services available through a grant from HOPWA. For HIV positive county    
    residents only. 

4) MARYLAND CHILDREN'S HEALTH PROGRAM: See separate listing.

5) HIV PREVENTION: Offers site-base HIV prevention throughout Baltimore County.       
    please call 410-887-6694.

6) SEROPOSITIVE CLINIC: Medical services to eligible HIV positive individuals provided 
    in conjunction with Johns Hopkins Hospital. Sliding scale fees. 

7) SUPPORT GROUP: Monthly support group for HIV positive individuals. 
 
TRANSPORTATION: Available for Eligible Clients Only.

VOLUNTEERS: No volunteers needed at this time.

Home visits: For established clients
eligibility: Anyone infected or affected by HIV/AIDS
fees: State and Federal funding for all services.
application_process: Call appropriate number to request service.

description:
Provides services for the prevention and treatment of breast and cervical cancer. Program offers literature and information at health fairs and workshops throughout the state.  Speakers are available for all types of community or professional events.

SCREENING
Eligibility: Women ages of 40 and over, are uninsured or underinsured, meet income guidelines, and are 250% below poverty level. Women ages 65 and older may qualify if they are receiving Medicare Part A only and have no other health insurance. Income Guidelines: 1 person, $24,500; 2 persons, $33,000.

o Enrolled participants are referred to local doctors' offices to receive free pap, pelvic and breast exams and mammograms. BCCP will set up the appointment and complete all necessary paperwork.  
                                                    
DIAGNOSTIC AND TREATMENT:
Eligibility: Women of any age with suspected cervical or breast cancer who are uninsured or underinsured and meet income guidelines: 1 person, $25,760; 2 persons, $29,850; 3 persons, $37,550; and 4 persons, $45,250.

o Provides referrals to local doctors' offices or treatment facilities for those women who are suspected of having cervical or breast cancer.  

VOLUNTEERS:  Administrative and intake opportunities are available for adults.

Home visits: No
eligibility: See notes.
name: Breast and Cervical Cancer Program, Baltimore County

o Fuel Fund assists residents with fuel bill bills after they have exhausted all other programs, such as MEAP, EUSP and FEMA. The utility company will give $1 in bill credit for every $2 that the fund gives.  Client is asked to pay percentage of the total bill.

o Financial Assistance provided for utilities, evictions, foreclosures and prescriptions when available.

o Reverse Mortgage Program: Elderly persons ages 62 and older, who own their own home with little or no mortgage may receive money based on their equity.  Repayment is due when the home is sold.

o Employment Assistance: Helps low-income individuals with job training, resume writing, interview techniques, job placement and motivation to pursue better paying jobs.

alternate_name: Day School Services Program, National Children's Center School
description:
Provides educational and related services for children and youth ages 12 to 21 with mental retardation, autism, and other developmental disabilities.

Home visits: Yes
eligibility: Local school system referral, diagnosed developmental disability.
name: Maryland School Program, National Children's Center (NCC)

description:
ELIGIBILITY:  Children with developmental disabilities including cerebral palsy, autism, Down syndrome, learning disabilities and serious emotional disturbance.  Also serves men and women with multiple and complex developmental disabilities.

OVERVIEW:  Participants work toward developmental goals, which are mapped out on an individualized service plan.  Each individual's plan is developed and implemented by a team of specialists along with the family, and is based on individual abilities and support needs. Teachers, psychologists, physical and occupational therapists, social workers, speech/language pathologists, nutritionists, physicians, and nurses work as a team to provide comprehensive services.

SERVICES:

1) EARLY INTERVENTION PROGRAM: Offers early intervention and preschool programs for infants and young children with and without disabilities. Individualized support services help young children overcome or learn to compensate for their delays and prepare them for successful school years. Participants learn to develop and/or improve skills in gross and fine motor movements, problem-solving, socialization, communication and language development, and activities of daily living like feeding, dressing, and toileting. 

2) SCHOOL PROGRAMS:  Offer various educational approaches using visual, auditory, and kinesthetic methods. Functional academics and life skills are taught, such as pedestrian safety, making purchases, paying bills, food preparation, cooking meals, and household cleaning tasks. Teachers, counselors, psychologists, physical and occupational therapists, social workers, speech pathologists, recreation specialists, nutritionists, physicians, and nurses work as a team to provide holistic services.

3)  RESIDENTIAL PROGRAMS:  Offer residential and transitional living homes for children, youth and adults. Independent apartments, and supervised apartments for men and women with developmental disabilities. Supports vary, based upon individual needs. Promotes independence and community integration.

4)  ADULT SERVICES:

 a)  ADULT DAY PROGRAM:  Offers participants  the opportunity to engage in structured, on-site activities focused on communication (including sign language and other alternatives to speech), expressive arts, physical fitness, socialization, adaptive living, and basic academics to help with everyday tasks. Also offers classes that build life skills such as preparing nutritious meals, maintaining good personal hygiene, and developing social skills. Includes excursions to libraries, restaurants, parks, and other local venues,  as well as participation in on-site music and dance activities that encourage creativity and self-expression.

 (b)  COMMUNITY BASED SERVICES:  Provide opportunities for participants to volunteer with local businesses and service organizations, with the support of NCC staff. The goal of volunteering is to enable them to develop new skills, learn in supportive and inclusive settings, and gain the satisfaction that comes from helping other people and giving back to the community. Currently, some clients volunteer at a local nursing home, a food pantry, a preschool, NCC's Value Village, and at many other nonprofit organizations.

 (c)  EMPLOYMENT OPTIONS:  Offers men and women with developmental disabilities a range of unique, person-centered career development and employment services. Pre-Vocational and Supported Employment service/career assessments, job training, volunteer work experiences, work clusters, job development and placements, job coaching, and follow-along supports.

5) National Children's Center operates five thrift stores -- known as Value Village -- in the Washington, DC/Maryland area. Value Village thrift stores directly support our services for children and adults with developmental disabilities.

description:
1) THRIFT STORE: Offers five thrift stores in Prince George's County. Used clothing, furniture, appliances and household goods available. Stoves and refrigerators not available. Clients who have written referrals from agencies that can verify need and income may receive coupons. Social workers may call 202-722-2300 on behalf of clients. No self-referrals accepted.

2) DONATIONS: Donations of clothing, furniture, appliances and household goods accepted. Home pick up services available in Anne Arundel, Howard, Montgomery, and Prince George's Counties. 

THRIFT STORE LOCATIONS:

1) 4917 Allentown Road, Suitland MD 20746. 301-967-0700. Mon-Sat, 9AM-8PM.

2) 6611 Annapolis Road,  Landover Hills MD. 1-301-341-4646. Mon-Sat. 9AM-8PM.

3) 2277 University Blvd, Adelphi, MD 20783

VOLUNTEERS: No volunteers needed.

Home visits: Yes
eligibility: Thrift stores open to the public.
fees: Prices vary according to condition of item.
application_process: Call appropriate number. See notes for Thrift Store.
name: National Children's Center/Value Village Thrift Store

description:
OVERVIEW: Offers used clothing, furniture, appliances and household goods available. Stoves and refrigerators not available. All items are 25% off on Mon for anyone.  Also, anyone may apply for a card which allows 25% on Thurs as well. 

DONATIONS: Donations of clothing, furniture (DOES NOT ACCEPT UPHOLSTERED FURNITURE), appliances and household goods accepted. Home pick up services available in Anne Arundel and Baltimore Counties and Baltimore City.  

See separate listing for D.C. locations.

VOLUNTEERS:  No volunteers needed.

Home visits: Yes
eligibility: Open to the public.
fees: Prices vary according to condition of item.
name: National Children's Center/Value Village Thrift Stores, MD

description:
TAX ASSISTANCE 2008:  For individuals with an income of $40,000 or less. Feb 1-Apr 15, 2008, Mon-Fri, 8:30AM-4:30PM (closed during lunch, 12:30PM-1:30PM and federal holidays). Walk ins only for Tax Assistance. Offers e-filing. Operates on a first come, first serve basis.

1) FEDERAL TAX INFORMATION/ASSISTANCE:  Call for information.

2) TELETAX RECORDED INFORMATION:  Provides information on 140 topics that answer many federal tax questions.  One can listen to three topics for each call made. Call 800-829-4477 (Maryland State).

3) FEDERAL TAX FORMS:  Call 800-829-3676.

4) REFUND HOTLINE:  Call 800-829-1954.                

5) PROBLEM RESOLUTION OFFICE:  Call 800-829-0115.

6) MARYLAND STATE INCOME TAX SERVICES: 1-800-638-2937 OR 1-800-MD-TAXES.

7) EARNED INCOME CREDIT (EIC):  A special tax credit for certain low-income workers.  The credit is subtracted from the tax that is owed.

o ELIGIBILITY:  

--  Employed persons who were raising one child in their home and have family income of less than $33,241 (or $35,241 for married workers) in 2007 can get EIC (up to $2,853).

--  Employed persons who were raising two or more children in their home and have family income of less than $37,783 (or $39,783 for married workers) in 2007 can get EIC (up to $4,716).  

--  Employed persons who are not raising children in their home, and who are between the ages of 25 and 64 on December 31, 2007 and had income below $12,590 (or $14,590 for married workers) can get EIC (up to $428).

o  APPLICATION:  For explanation of EIC or forms and publication information, call 800-829-3676. Schedule EIC must be attached to form 1040 or 1040A. The 1040EZ does not require the schedule EIC.

VOLUNTEERS:  Volunteers not recruited for this program.

Home visits: No
eligibility: Adults 18 and older.
name: Internal Revenue Service, Allegany County Office

description:
TAX ASSISTANCE:  For individuals with an income of $40,000 or less. Feb 1-Apr 15, 2008, Mon-Fri, 8:30AM-4:30PM (closed during lunch 12:30-1:30PM and all federal holidays). Walk-ins for Tax Assistance -- first come, first served. Offers e-filing. 

1) FEDERAL TAX INFORMATION AND ASSISTANCE:  Call for information.

8) SELF-HELP TAX RETURN PREPARATION ASSISTANCE:  Walk-in tax return preparation assistance during the tax season. Instructors assist taxpayers filling out forms. 

9) EARNED INCOME CREDIT (EIC):  A special tax credit for certain low-income workers. The credit is subtracted from the tax that is owed.
o ELIGIBILITY:

--  Employed persons who were raising two or more children in their home and have family income of less than $37,783 (or $39,783 for married workers) in 2007 can get EIC (up to $4,716).  

--  Employed persons who are not raising children in their home, and who are between the ages of 25 and 64 on December 31, 2007 and had income below $12,590 (or $14,590 for married workers) can get EIC (up to $428).

o  APPLICATION:  For explanation of EIC or forms and publication information, call 800-829-3676. Schedule EIC must be attached to form 1040 or 1040A. The 1040EZ does not require the schedule EIC.

VOLUNTEERS:  This program does not recruit volunteers.

description:
TAX ASSISTANCE 2008: Offered from Feb 4 through April 15, at two locations: 
3717 Springdale Avenue 21216 and 3939 Reisterstown Road 21215, 9:30AM-5PM, Mon-Fri. Call 410-664-4300 for appointment. Offered to seniors, physically disabled persons and persons with income (AGI) under $40,000, by appointment only;  E-filing only. 

Applicants must bring:
 --  Valid photo ID for self and spouse
 --  A Social Security card for EACH family member.
 --  W-2 forms for all jobs worked in 2007.
 --  Child care provider - name, address and tax ID number.
 --  All banking account information (a voided check and/or savings deposit slip). 
 --  A copy of last year's tax return.
 --  Any document or information about money received from the IRS, including the      advanced Child Tax Credit.
 --  All 1099 forms for other income, if any.
 --  Any other tax related documents.
NOTE: Every adult listed on the tax form must come to sign the return

Home visits: No
eligibility: See Notes.

description:
OVERVIEW: Provides low cost health care for individuals and families.

SERVICES: Provides physical exams; immunizations for children and adults; GYN exam/pap smears; family planning; blood pressure and blood sugar monitoring; health education on multiple topics; and health problems counseling.

VOLUNTEERS: None needed at this time.

Home visits: No
eligibility: Open to the public.
fees: All insurance, Medicaid, Medicare, and private pay. Also offers sliding fee scale.
application_process: Appointments are preferred, but the client can walk in.
name: Coppin State University, Community Health Center

description:
1) SUPPORT GROUPS: For caregivers and children regarding a variety of family-related issues.  Just for Us, a support group for grandparents and caregivers, is held the 
2nd Sat of each month at Second Antioch Church on 2001 E. Baltimore St.  All About Us, a support group for children, is held the 4th Sat of each month on Coppin's campus.  Project Garrison, another support group for children, is held the 3rd Sat of the month at Garrison Middle School.

2) INFORMATION/REFERRALS: Provides referrals for food, shelter, childcare centers, detox and recovery, counseling, housing, workshops, social services, support groups, assistance with getting school clothing, job training, mental health services and GED. Also provides information re: where Kinship Caregivers can be connected to food baskets.

3) WORKSHOPS: Provides information and referrals on a variety of topics related to kinship care, i.e. legal, substance abuse, children's mental health, information and referrals educational health.

4) HOME ASSESSMENTS: Provided for follow-up services.

5) DONATIONS HOLIDAY: In need of monetary donations for the annual Christmas dinner (for Kinship Caregivers and their children). Money preferred, but any donations (food items, toys, etc.) will be accepted.  Individuals or agencies are needed to Adopt-a -family for Thanksgiving and Christmas (gifts and food for both). Food items need to be non-perishable.

6) OUTREACH SOCIAL WORKER: Available as needed.

7) MEETING ROOM: Available for conferences. Must be previously scheduled.

VOLUNTEERS: Adult volunteers needed.

Home visits: For established clients
eligibility: Caregivers (other than parents) and children being raised by caregivers.
application_process: Call for information or walk in.
name: Kinship Care Resource Center of Maryland

description:
OVERVIEW: Provides permanent housing for formerly homeless men, 18 and older, who have mental health and substance abuse issues and have successfully completed substance abuse treatment programs and/or transitional housing programs. Case management is provided for referral to appropriate services.

VOLUNTEERS: Not needed at this time.
eligibility: See notes.
application_process: Referral required from case worker.  Will need Picture ID, Social Security card, Birth Certificate, proof of income and medical/psychiatric records.
name: Arundel House of Hope, Community Supportive Housing

description:
OVERVIEW: Provides hospitality such as coffee, snacks, showers, use of phones and computers, clothing and toiletries.  Case management and referral to services are provided for applications for benefits, medical care, job assistance, substance abuse treatment programs, housing anD other identified issues. 

VOLUNTEERS: Needs volunteers, 18 and over for administrative duties; assisting clients with clothing and other requests; and transportation to appointments.

Home visits: No
eligibility: Homeless men and women over 18 years old.
application_process: Walk-in for services.  Some may require a sign in, such as case management and referral.  Picture ID needed.

eligibility: Men, 18 and over, who have recently completed a substance abuse treatment program.
application_process: Call for more information. Referral required from case worker.  Will need Picture ID and medical/psychiatric records.

VOLUNTEERS: Not needed at this time.

description:
SERVICES: 
1) HOTLINE:  Offers substance abuse crisis intervention to persons in need.

2) SUBSTANCE ABUSE ASSESSMENT/COUNSELING:  Provides assessments and individual counseling for drug and or alcohol addictions.

3) SUPPORT GROUPS:  Provides support groups for persons with addictions and their family and friends on Thursday, 7-8:30PM at Transformation Church of Jesus Christ, 5150 Baltimore National Pike, Baltimore, Maryland.

4) OUTREACH/EDUCATION:  Provides substance abuse prevention presentations and distributes literature to schools, prisons, church groups and fairs.

5) INFORMATION & REFERRAL:  Offers referrals for detoxification programs and for services to homeless individuals/families.

VOLUNTEERS:  Volunteers, ages 25 and older, needed to assist with support group and to distribute substance abuse literature.

Home visits: Limited
eligibility: Persons with drug and/or alcohol addictions, ages 19 and older.

description:
OVERVIEW: Offers a comprehensive program of interdisciplinary home health care services to patients and their families/significant others.

SERVICES:
--Management of pain and other symptoms.
--Emotional support.
--Caregiver respite.
--Case Management, including locating & coordinating appropriate community resources.
--Coordination of medication management, equipment and supplies related to the terminal illness.
--Individual and family counseling services.
--Emergency on-call nursing services 24 hours/day, 7 days/week.
--Bereavement services to patient's family for up to thirteen months following the loss.
--Companionship, assistance with patients activities of daily living and daily  chores.

VOLUNTEERS: Adult volunteers are needed. Duties include assisting patients and families with errands, companionship, caregiving and respite, meal preparation, light chores and personal grooming. Volunteers also needed for bereavement phone calls to families after loss. Administrative assistants are needed for a variety of office duties.

Home visits: Yes
eligibility: Individuals of all ages diagnosed with a terminal illness with less than 6 months to live (and their families).
fees: Private insurance, Medicare, Medicaid and private pay.

BUS:  # 5

SERVICES:                                                                                           
1) CLOTHING:  Used men's, women's and children's clothing is available to anyone in need, on the third Tues of the month, Noon-3PM.

2) EMERGENCY GROCERIES:  A 2-4-day supply of canned goods  is available.  Clients may receive food once every 30 days. However, in the case of an extreme emergency, this rule can be waived, but a  referral would be necessary. I.D. is required.

Documentation:  All applicants must provide a photo ID. First-time applicants must bring a Social Security card for each member of the household or Independence cards, and if the children's last names are different from the parent's last name, the children's birth certificates must also be provided.  A photo-copy of these documents will be kept on file.

o THANKSGIVING: A holiday meal will be offered to anyone in need. Nov. 19th 5PM.  Walk in.  No referral or sign up necessary.

Eligibility will be determined on a case-by-case basis. Clients will be mailed a postcard if they will receive assistance. If eligible, must provide two forms of ID (one must be a photo ID) for entire household, and proof of household members.

description:
OVERVIEW: Oversees and administers all state social services programs.

SERVICES:
1) ADOPTION: Provides information on all aspects of adoption, especially children with special needs. Call 1-800-392-3678.

2) ADULT PROTECTIVE SERVICES: See separate listing. "Vulnerable Adult Hotline", 
1-800-332-6347.

3) CHILD PROTECTIVE SERVICES: Receives reports on any suspected incidents of child abuse or neglect. Call 1-800-332-6347.

4) CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT: Provides information regarding child support. Call 1-800-332-6347.

5) DISABILITY ENTITLEMENT ADVOCACY PROGRAM: Assists disabled citizens with applying for and obtaining TEMHA benefits from Department of Social Services or SSI/SSDI from the Social Security Administration. Call 1-800-727-6454.

6) DISCRIMINATION COMPLAINTS: Receives complaints of discrimination because of race, color, age, sex, national origin, political beliefs, disability or religion. Call 1-800-332-6347.

7) FOSTER CARE: Provides information on all aspects of foster care, especially of children with special needs. Call 1-800-555-1345.

8) INDEPENDENCE CARD: Call local DSS office. 

9) OFFICE OF HOME ENERGY PROGRAMS (OHEP): See separate listing. Call 1-800-352-1446.
Eligibility Guidelines for July 1, 2007 - June 30, 2008
FAMILY SIZE         GROSS MONTHLY INCOME           MAXIMUM YEARLY
1                             $ 1,488.96                                      $ 17,867.50                        
2                             $ 1,996.46                                      $ 23,957.50              
3                             $ 2,503.96                                      $ 30,047.50         
4                             $ 3,011.46                                      $ 36,137.50                        
5                             $ 3,518.96                                      $ 42,227.50                       
6                             $ 4,026.46                                      $ 48,317.50
                                                                                                   
For each additional person, add $ 507.50                         $ 6,090      	

10) PRIMARY PREVENTION INITIATIVE (PPI): Answers questions about PPI, Maryland's program to promote preventive health care, immunizations, and school attendance for all TCA children. Call 1-800-742-7301.

11) WELFARE FRAUD: Persons can report suspected welfare fraud in Maryland. Call 1-800-332-6347. (1-800-732-7850 - Spanish)

12) PROJECT RETAIN: Strengthens job success for low wage workers by offering local support services and job retention activities. Helps employers keep workers on the job.  Call 1-800-742-7301.

13) MARYLAND OFFICE FOR NEW AMERICANS (MONA): See separate listing.  Includes directory of state resources for ethnic organizations. Call 410-767-8970.

14) TAX ASSISTANCE 2008: Call for appointment or walk in Mon, Tues, and Thurs 8:30-3PM (May be able to accommodate other days if not busy), between  Feb 1-April 1, 2008. Call Larry Ingram at 410-767-7466 for appointment if desired.  E-filing is standard, mail-in can sometimes be accommodated.

Applicants must bring:
 --  Valid photo ID for self and spouse
  --  A Social Security card for EACH family member.
  --  W-2 forms for all jobs worked in 2007.
  --  Child care provider - name, address and tax ID number.
  --  All banking account information (a voided check and/or savings deposit slip). 
  --  A copy of last year's tax return.
  --  Any document or information about money received from the IRS, including the advanced Child Tax Credit.
  --  All 1099 forms for other income, if any.
  --  Any other tax related documents.
NOTE: Every adult listed on the tax form must come to sign the return
 
VOLUNTEERS: None needed at this time.

APPLICATION:  Need to submit a copy of photo identity, proof of residence, copies of Social Security cards for all household members (including children), proof of household's total gross income for 30 days prior to application date (from all sources), name of home energy supplier and account number, a copy of the most recent utility bill and a copy of the lease (if renting).

1) OFFICE OF HOME ENERGY PROGRAMS:  Provides MEAP and EUSP grants to eligible families, renters, roomers, boarders, and homeowners toward the cost of heating in the winter and electricity year round. Grant is based on the type of fuel used, household size, household income and annual consumption. 

2)  EUSP (Electrical Universal Service Program):  Assists with electric utility bill payment. Client is required to have bill in his/her own name and be on a monthly budget billing plan. Some funds are available for a one time only benefit for past due bill payments.

3) FURNACES: Limited funds are available for clients to be referred to the weatherization office for furnace repair, replacement and/or other weatherization procedures.

4) WEATHERIZATION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM:  See separate listing.

VOLUNTEERS: Age 16 and over are welcome.

Home visits: Yes
eligibility: See notes.
name: Maryland Dept. of Human Resources, Off. of Home Energy Programs

description:
OVERVIEW: A statewide surplus food commodities program that supplies pantries with free, surplus food from the United States Department of Agriculture. Interested parties may call the contact listed for the appropriate county.

ELIGIBILITY: A household is eligible if it is currently certified for any of the following programs: Food Stamps, TCA, TEMHA, Medical Assistance or MEAP. Households with incomes below 150% of the federal poverty guidelines are also eligible:

HOUSEHOLD SIZE         TOTAL HOUSEHOLD INCOME/MONTH   
1                                              $1,488.96
2                                              $1,996.46
3                                              $2,503.96                            	
4                                              $3,011.46
5                                              $3,518.96
6                                              $4,026.46

For each additional person, add $507.50

NOTE: Income eligibility standards change every fiscal year. 

INTAKE PROCEDURE: Recipients must receive food in their county (including Baltimore City) of residence. An adult should go to the nearest site during the hours of distribution. Unless applicants are pre-registered, they must prove eligibility with documents indicating current address and either current certification for one of the programs listed above, or amounts and sources of household income. Garrett County REQUIRES pre-registration. If homebound, contact the local distributing agency.
